title: TD Bank plans to shutter 6 Mass. branches amid nationwide closures
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: TD Bank will close six branches and one remote drive-thru in Massachusetts as part of a plan to shutter 51 locations nationwide.
The closures are part of TD Bank's strategy to enhance U.S. retail presence through digital banking and network evaluations.
TD Bank states that the closures are unrelated to a $1.8 billion anti-money laundering settlement with the U.S. government.

title: Longtime 7News anchor Kim Khazei is signing off
author: John Waller
bullets: Kim Khazei, a 7News anchor since 1994, will leave the station at the end of the year.
Khazei anchors the 5, 6, 10, and 11 p.m. news with co-anchor Adam Williams.
Khazei is relocating to be closer to family after a long career at WHDH-TV/WLVI-TV.

title: Payton Pritchard addresses his shooting woes as Celtics struggle as a whole
author: Aidan Buchanan
bullets: Payton Pritchard remains confident despite Celtics' poor 3-point shooting, currently averaging 31.2%, second worst in the league.
Celtics are struggling with a 3-5 start this season, notably impacted by their shooting performance against the Jazz.
Coach Joe Mazzulla attributes shooting issues to a change in play-style and players adapting to new demands.

title: How Mass. native Georges Niang reacted to Celtics’ decision to trade him
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Georges Niang was briefly with the Celtics after a trade involving Kristaps Porzingis, then quickly moved to Utah.
Niang praised Brad Stevens for his transparency during his short time with the Boston Celtics.
Niang, dealing with a foot injury, missed Utah's narrow win over the Celtics but holds no hard feelings about the trade.

title: Two Mass. men arrested in Harvard Medical School explosion
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: Logan David Patterson, 18, and Dominick Frank Cardoza, 20, were arrested for a Harvard Medical School explosion on November 1, 2025.
The explosion, caused by a large commercial firework, occurred at the Goldenson Building, causing no injuries or structural damage.
Surveillance footage and public tips led to the identification and arrest of the suspects; no motive has been determined yet.

title: ‘This has nothing to do with us,’ BPD commissioner says amid Karen Read attorney’s calls for disciplinary review
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: Boston Police Commissioner Michael Cox rebuffs attorney's calls for disciplinary review over testimony in Karen Read's trial.
Attorney Alan Jackson accused Cox of lying about his knowledge of former officer Kelly Dever's involvement in the case.
Cox denies meddling in the trial and requests not to be questioned further, stating it doesn't pertain to the police department.

title: Missing Worcester woman found dead in car
author: Madison Lucchesi
bullets: Joanna Brown, 30, was found dead in her 2025 Mitsubishi Outlander on Mount Vernon St. in Worcester.
Brown was last seen on Friday at the Bean Counter Bakery Cafe and reported missing by her family on Sunday.
The Worcester County District Attorney’s Office and Worcester Police are investigating the cause of Brown's death.

title: Here’s why Conde Nast Traveler just named Boston one of the best places to go in 2026
author: Kristi Palma
bullets: Conde Nast Traveler named Boston as a top 2026 destination due to its rich history and vibrant events.
Highlighted 2026 events include Sail Boston with historic ships and the FIFA World Cup matches.
Boston's culinary scene with venues like Comfort Kitchen and Row 34 also drew praise from Conde Nast Traveler.

title: Milan Lucic joining AHL’s Springfield Thunderbirds for professional tryout
author: Hayden Bird
bullets: Milan Lucic, 37, joins AHL's Springfield Thunderbirds on a professional tryout after recovering from an injury.
Lucic last played for the Boston Bruins in 2023 and completed the NHL player assistance program this summer.
Lucic has 1,177 NHL regular-season games with 586 points, including stints with the Kings, Oilers, and Flames.

title: Seth Meyers responds after Trump calls him a ‘deranged lunatic’ for ‘probably illegal’ late-night jokes
author: Kevin Slane
bullets: Seth Meyers responded to Donald Trump's Truth Social post calling him a 'deranged lunatic' after mocking Trump's speech.
Trump criticized Meyers, calling his jokes 'probably illegal', due to jokes about catapult technology on aircraft carriers.
Meyers countered Trump's attacks during his show's monologue, highlighting Trump's repetitive focus on catapults in speeches.
